Silver Spring, MD - The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is pleased to announce new updates to the nutrition facts labeling requirements for packaged foods. These changes are aimed at providing consumers with more accurate and up-to-date information to make informed decisions about their dietary choices.

Effective immediately, manufacturers will be required to include the amount of added sugars in grams and as a percent Daily Value on the Nutrition Facts label. This addition will help consumers better understand the amount of sugar that is added to a product during processing, separate from naturally occurring sugars in ingredients.

In addition to the added sugars declaration, the updated labeling requirements will also include changes to the format of the label to make it more user-friendly and easier to read. This includes increasing the font size for "Calories," "Serving Size," and "Servings Per Container" to highlight these key pieces of information for consumers.

The FDA believes that these updates will empower consumers to make healthier choices by providing them with clearer and more transparent information about the nutritional content of the foods they consume. By making these changes, we are working to support public health efforts to reduce the prevalence of diet-related diseases and promote overall well-being.

Manufacturers are encouraged to comply with these new requirements promptly to ensure that consumers have access to the most accurate and helpful information when making food choices.

The FDA's new recommendations aim to improve the accuracy and consistency of allergen labels on packaged food products, ensuring that individuals with food allergies can make well-informed choices about the foods they consume.

According to the updated guidelines, food manufacturers are encouraged to clearly and prominently display allergen information on their product labels. The FDA also recommends that allergen information be placed in a consistent location on the packaging to facilitate quick and easy identification for consumers.

It is crucial for individuals with food allergies to have access to accurate and reliable allergen information to prevent potentially life-threatening reactions. By implementing these new guidelines, food manufacturers can help ensure that consumers have the information they need to make safe and informed food choices.

The FDA remains committed to promoting food safety and transparency in the food industry. We encourage food manufacturers to adhere to these updated guidelines and prioritize the accurate labeling of allergens on their products to better serve consumers with food allergies.
